reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s scale/population-ethics-driven route to “fussiness” (e.g., claims that solar-system utopia is negligible vs cosmic expansion under linear/totalist assumptions). That strand is important but not the whole case: the paper also argues for fragility via many non-scale moral catastrophes and (in Section 3) for fussiness across many bounded/unbounded value-function families, so undermining scale arguments would weaken rather than collapse the overall position (moderate centrality). The critique does provide a real challenge to the ‘rounding error’ rhetoric by noting population ethics is deeply unsettled and that many plausible views (person-affecting/average-constrained/rights-based) don’t treat “more lives/expansion” as straightforwardly better; it also flags an extra assumption about scalability of high welfare. However, it doesn’t engage the paper’s broader claim that many non-expansion-related dimensions can still make mostly-great futures rare, nor does it show that population-ethics uncertainty implies easygoingness rather than a different kind of fussiness/target-narrowness. Most claims are accurate, though the move from “uncertainty” to “robust satisficing” is more suggestive than argued. Clear and focused with little filler.
title: Population ethics uncertainty undermines scale-based moral fussiness
